title: The Purpose Revealed
teaser: Loving God with everything we have left transforms what we have lost
theme: Discovering that loving God completely means embracing His plan with every dimension of our being

modules.greekOriginal: καὶ ἠγάπησας κύριον τὸν θεόν σου ἐξ ὅλης τῆς καρδίας σου καὶ ἐξ ὅλης τῆς ψυχῆς σου καὶ ἐξ ὅλης τῆς διανοίας σου καὶ ἐξ ὅλης τῆς ἰσχύος σου.
modules.passage: And you shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your mind, and with all your strength.

modules.meaning: to love with deliberate choice and commitment
modules.rootMeaning: Agape love is not primarily emotional but volitional. It is a deliberate choice to seek another's highest good regardless of feelings or circumstances.
modules.usageNote: Jesus quotes from the Shema (Deuteronomy 6:4-5), the central confession of Jewish faith. By citing this, He affirmed that love for God should be the organizing principle of all human existence.

relatedWords.reference: kardia - heart. The center of personality including emotions, will, and moral character.
psyche - soul. The animating life force, the very essence of what makes us alive.
dianoia - mind. The faculty of thinking, reasoning, and intellectual engagement.
ischys - strength. Physical power, capacity for action, practical ability.

modules.definition: To love with deliberate, volitional commitment that seeks another's highest good regardless of personal cost or circumstance.
modules.usage: The future indicative form suggests this should be the ongoing orientation of life, not a momentary feeling but a sustained, chosen direction.

modules.body:
In 1979, Joni founded 'Joni and Friends,' a ministry dedicated to serving people with disabilities worldwide. She began speaking internationally, wrote over 50 books, recorded musical albums, and starred in a biographical film. Her mouth-painted artwork has been exhibited globally. She married Ken Tada in 1982.

How does someone paralyzed from the shoulders down love God with all their strength? Joni's life answers that question with breathtaking clarity.

When Jesus quoted the Shema, He presented love for God as engaging four dimensions of human existence: heart (emotional and volitional center), soul (life essence and vitality), mind (intellectual and rational faculties), and strength (physical and practical capabilities). The phrase 'with all' is repeated four times, emphasizing totality: no part of our being should be excluded.

Joni's accident forced her to redefine what it meant to love God with all her strength when her physical strength was gone. She discovered that loving God with all her strength did not require physical ability. It required complete dedication of whatever capacities she retained. Her paralyzed body became the instrument through which she loved God with unprecedented intensity.
modules.keyInsight: Loving God with all our strength does not require having all our strength. It requires giving everything we have, whatever that looks like.

modules.heading: Four Dimensions of Love

modules.body:
By founding Joni and Friends, Joni discovered that losing her physical abilities led to gaining spiritual influence beyond her wildest imagination. The ministry now operates in over 45 countries, has distributed millions of wheelchairs, and has reached countless people with the Gospel.

But the scope of her ministry is not what makes Joni's story remarkable. What makes it remarkable is the love behind it. She did not build a disability ministry because she wanted to be famous. She built it because she loved God with everything she had left, and everything she had left turned out to be enough.

Her heart chose to love God through daily pain. Her soul clung to life with fierce purpose. Her mind engaged deeply with theology, writing, and speaking. And her strength, redefined by paralysis, poured itself into every brushstroke, every spoken word, every act of advocacy. Four dimensions of love, all fully engaged, all radiating from a wheelchair.
modules.connectionToTheme: Joni's purpose was revealed not despite her limitations but through them. Loving God with everything she had transformed what she had lost into something far greater.

modules.heading: Everything She Had Left

modules.body:
The Shema (Deuteronomy 6:4-5) was the central confession of Jewish faith, recited twice daily by observant Jews. When Jesus cited it as the greatest commandment, He was affirming the foundational truth that love for God should be the organizing principle of all human existence.

The fourfold structure Jesus presents is not accidental. It covers every dimension of the human person:

Heart (kardia): Our emotional and volitional center, where we feel and choose.
Soul (psyche): Our life essence, the animating force that makes us who we are.
Mind (dianoia): Our intellectual faculties, where we think, reason, and understand.
Strength (ischys): Our physical and practical capabilities, how we act in the world.

The theological implications are demanding. This kind of love is comprehensive, leaving no compartment of life untouched. It is transformative, reordering all other relationships and priorities. And it is, frankly, impossible by human effort alone. This standard reveals our need for God's grace, as no human loves God perfectly. But it also reveals a stunning truth: God accepts our imperfect, limited, broken offering of love when it is given wholeheartedly.
modules.historicalContext: The Shema was recited twice daily by observant Jews and was considered the most important statement of faith in Judaism. Jesus affirming it as the greatest commandment was not controversial. His radical addition was connecting it to love of neighbor as the second greatest.
modules.fascinatingFact: The repetition of 'with all' (ex holes) four times creates a rhetorical structure emphasizing totality. In Hebrew poetic tradition, repetition indicates emphasis and completeness. Nothing is left out of the call to love God.

modules.heading: The Greatest Commandment

modules.ancientTruth: The Shema commanded ancient Israel to love God with every dimension of their being, holding nothing back from His lordship.
modules.modernApplication: We compartmentalize our lives, giving God our Sunday mornings but keeping our careers, relationships, and ambitions under our own control. The Shema permits no such division.
modules.connectionPoint: Joni's wheelchair eliminated the possibility of compartmentalization. She could not give God part of herself because her limitations demanded that every remaining capacity be oriented toward Him. Her constraint became her freedom.
modules.newTestamentEcho: Paul expressed this total love: 'For to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain.' (Philippians 1:21) True love for God means He becomes the purpose behind every dimension of our existence.

modules.prompt: What does loving God completely look like in your particular circumstances?
additionalQuestions: Which of the four dimensions (heart, soul, mind, strength) do you find easiest to give to God? Which is hardest?
How has God revealed His purpose through your most difficult seasons?
What would change if you dedicated every remaining capacity you have to loving God?

modules.prayerText: Father, I want to love You with my entire being. I give You my heart with all its emotions and choices. I give You my soul with all its vitality and passion. I give You my mind with all its thoughts and questions. I give You my strength with all its capacity and limitation. Help me embrace Your plan completely, trusting that Your purposes are perfect even when I cannot see them. Show me the purpose You are revealing through my struggles. Amen.

modules.commitment: Today I will choose one dimension where I have been holding back from God (heart, soul, mind, or strength) and take a specific step to love Him more fully in that area.
leavingAtCross: The compartmentalization that keeps parts of my life from God
The lie that my limitations disqualify me from loving God fully
The expectation that purpose requires perfection
receivingFromCross: The truth that God accepts my imperfect but wholehearted love
The revelation that purpose emerges through limitations, not despite them
The freedom to love God with everything I have, not everything I wish I had
modules.content: Today I will choose one dimension where I have been holding back from God (heart, soul, mind, or strength) and take a specific step to love Him more fully in that area.

forReflection: How does Joni's story redefine what it means to love God 'with all your strength'?
What purpose might God be revealing through your current limitations?
How can the four dimensions of love (heart, soul, mind, strength) guide your spiritual growth?
forAccountabilityPartners: Share which dimension of love you find most difficult to give to God and why
Ask each other: What purpose might God be working through your current struggles?
Challenge each other to love God more fully in one specific area this week
